_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Program is based on Program 1 requirements. It contains a worst case scenario, management's response to a chemical release in the form of a "Team Assignment Checklist" and a summary of discussion with police  and fire departments.

Determining the Worst Case Scenario         
The worst - case scenario was determined by finding the largest vessel allowed containing the most ammonia. This vessel is also located outside. This vessel is the ammonia receiver located on the south side of the plant.  According to the Plant Engineer, this vessel could contain as much as 10,000 lbs. of ammonia, which is the maximum capacity of the receiver. This amount used as the quantity Q since for the worst - case scenario, the vessel is assumed to be full.  The time of release is 10 minutes. The rate of release, R, is calculated as 10000 lbs. / 10 minutes = 1000 lbs. / minute.    

Q = 10000 lbs. ammonia
T= 10 minutes
R=1000lbs. ammonia / minute        

Using Exhibit 4-4 from the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration with a release rate of 1000 lbs / min, the distance to the endpoint is 1.2 miles. This radius and the surrounding area are drawn on the city map of Omaha.  Using information from the Census Bureau, the population  enclosed by a radius of 1.2 miles from the source is 2,370.            

Continuation of Executive Summary Management's Response to a Chemical Release Enclosed is a "Team Assignment Checklist" which assigns responsibilities to members of management in the event of a chemical release.

Discussion with Local Police and Fire Departments Kathleen Krantz and Ross Ashbacher met with officials from both the Omaha police and fire departments. Topics that were discussed included vapor cloud monitoring, public notification, site, and traffic control, and emergency rescue.

Vapor Cloud Monitoring Greater Omaha, the police department, and fire department, will collaborate on vapor cloud monitoring and keep each party informed of its progress.

Greater Omaha Packing will notify media of chemical threat.

Public Notification Greater Omaha Packing will notify media of chemical release and precautions that the public should take such as staying indoors with the doors closed and windows shut.

Site and Traffic Control 
The police department agreed to provide site and traffic control for Greater Omaha Packing in the event of a release. The worst case scenario was discussed and police reviewed areas that would be affected. Police reviewed possible sites to restrict or block traffic.

Emergency Rescue 
The fire department has agreed to provide emergency rescue operations at Greater Omaha Packing as necessary and to the public as well in the event of a chemical release.

Program
We certify to the best of our knowledge and ability, that the above program
meets Program 1 requirements for EPA's Risk Management Program for Greater
Omaha Packing.

Kathleen Krantz, Technical Resource Director    Ross Ashbacher, Safety Coordinator
    9/7/99        9/7/99
    Date        Date
